|Title=Morbidity and mortality meetings (RMM): understanding the principles and objectives of a RMM
|Description=None
|Rubric=Definition
|Contributors=Virginie Migeot
|Order=7}}

The morbidity-mortality meeting (MMM) is a ''collective, retrospective and systemic analysis meeting'' (i.e. taking into account the organisational, technical and human components) of clinical situations marked by the occurrence of an undesirable event associated with care (death, complication, etc.), in order to implement ''prevention, recovery or mitigation actions''. RMMs are part of the ''feedback culture'' or how to learn collectively from mistakes. RMMs can be used to validate the continuing professional development (CPD) obligation.

'''Link to item 4''' Quality and safety of care. Patient safety. Risk management. Undesirable events associated with care (EIAS). Quality approach and assessment of professional practices

question.title: What is the primary purpose of a morbidity-mortality meeting (RMM)?
question.description: A multiple-choice question about the purpose of RMMs

option_a.title: To identify and implement new treatment protocols
option_a.description: A plausible but incorrect option that could be tempting for those who focus on the procedural aspects of RMMs

option_b.title: To improve patient outcomes and reduce morbidity and mortality
option_b.description: A correct option that aligns with the definition of RMMs

option_c.title: To evaluate the effectiveness of existing care pathways
option_c.description: A distractor that could be confusing for those who focus on the technical aspects of RMMs

option_d.title: To assign blame and criticize healthcare professionals
option_d.description: A distractor that could be tempting for those who focus on the negative aspects of RMMs

correct_option.title: B
correct_option.description: A letter indicating the correct answer
